EDITORIAL.
'IF IF V
4711IF
V V V
VVOVVVVV.

VERY important and vital question in the undergraduate affairs of
most leading American universities is the question of Fraternities.
0
It has been a custom, here at Hopkins, not to discuss any phase of
the Fraternity question in the columns of the Nicws-Lornoz. This
custom, one might almost call it a tradition, has obtained ever since
the foundation of the paper ten years or so ago. But customary
V
though it has been, there is no rule which prohibits such discussions
ISVVVVV*
in this paper and after seriously considering the question, the Board
Editors of the NEWS-LETTER has come to the conclusion that the
of
11
publication of such Fraternity news as would be of interest to other
Fraternities, would tend to bring about better feeling among the Fraternities here at Hopkins. Almost all the other college papers in this country publish such news; some have a
regular "Fraternity" column. Why should not we ? All of us know that one of the
Fraternities here held a Convention in Philadelphia lately; that a member of the Junior Class
was a delegate to the Convention of another Fraternity in Minnesota ten days ago; and that
the Alumni Banquet of a third Fraternity had to be called off owing to the death of one of its
officers. Why ,should not such news be published in this .paper ? It would be of interest to
the student-body; it would interest our subscribers among the Alumni.
Another side of the question is the much-mooted proposition of an inter-fraternity organization, in the nature of a Pan-Hellenic. The NEws-LETTER believes that such an organization, if begun and carried on in the right way, would be of great benefit to the University.
But we can, of course, do nothing to start such a movement. The initiative must come from
the Fraternities themselves. But if such an initiative does come, our columns are at the disposal of all those Who care to discuss their views or suggest plans. Two things, however,
must be emphasized. A Pan-Hellenic must be an entirely non-secret society, and it must be
representative of all of our fraternities.

HE good showing of the Glee and Mandolin Clubs at the Roland
Park Concert is gratifying, and the two leaders, Messrs. Ruth and
Hughes, and the manager, Mr. Pedrick, deserve great credit. The
condition of the Clubs looked rather "sad" at the commencement of
the winter, but steady hard work and determination have at last
really "rounded them into" that "shape" which has so often been
foretold in this paper, in various articles on the Musical Clubs. On
the night of March 13, the date on which this number of the NEWSLETTER appears, there is going to be, as we trust all of you know, a
joint concert by the Musical Clubs of the Woman's College and
Hopkins. Everybody must be there. May it be a great success!

The NEWS-LETTER announces with much regret the resignation of Mr. Alan Chesney,
Athletic Editor. Mr. Chesney was elected to the Board in the spring of his freshman year,
and has worked faithfully and conscientiously for the good of the paper.
We are glad to announce the election of Mr. G. R. Veazey, '10, as an Assistant NewsEditor, and of Mr. Boyd Wylie, '10, as Assistant Business Manager.
SOME TRANSLATIONS BY A MEMBER OF THE CLASS OF 1903.

V.—THE HOUR OF EXTASY.
FROM VERLAINE.

The white moon slants through the gloomy
wood,
From every branch, a voice is heard
In the foliage dark,
Beloved, hark!
From the bank of the stream,
As in a mirror, is seen
The shadow of the willow
The breeze tells of Love's power.
Let us dream !
'Tis the hour !
A vast and tender peace from on high
Descends from yon star in the purple sky
Tis the hour of Extasy !

A LETTER.
[We have received the following letter, which may be
of interest to some student.—ED.]

1964 EIGHTY-FOURTH STREET,
BROOKLYN, N. Y., Feb. 24, '08
DEAR SIR:
Is there a young man in your University,
who would like to make a little "extra"
money?
I am the patentee of an inexpensive, though
striking, Decorative Idea, specially adapted
for walls of college rooms, dens, libraries, etc.,
and will give a liberal discount, from 30 to 40
per cent., according to number of orders
received.
Will be pleased to send the Decoration in
your University colors, if you will send
samples of the shades and 50c. in stamps.
Your name was given me by one of the
staff of "The Stute," Stevens Institute,
Hoboken, N. J.
Trusting to hear favorably from you, I am,
Very truly yours,
(Miss) EVA SWITZER.

ELEVENTH ANNUAL INTERCLASS DEBATE AND PUBLIC SPEAKING.
As usual, the Interclass Debate and Public
Speaking Contest proved to be a very interesting affair. This event has become quite
popular, and is looked forward to by a great
many, as was shown by the crowded condition
of McCoy Hall. The program was of the
customary style, being opened with a selection
by the Mandolin Club as the speakers and
judges entered. Dr. French, who presided
over the occasion, then introduced the orators.
Mr. Louis Leopold Mann delivered most
excellently a speech on "True Americanism."
The judges awarded the prize to Mr. Mann,
although they were not unanimous in their
decision. They thought that it was a close
race between Mr. Mann and Mr. Deale, who
made "A Plea for Cuba." Mr. Deale's
delivery was very good and his voice filled
the hall. After the decision of the judges
was announced by L. Edwin Goldman, Esq.,
the Glee Club sang "Rah for Black and Blue."
During this song the students in the back of
the hall joined in the chorus, which tended to
make things more lively and not so solemn as

they usually are on this occasion. The
audience was so appreciative and applauded
so long that, even though the Glee Club had
gone around to the rear of the hall, they sang
"Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land."
Then catne the debate—the really serious
part of the, program. The question which
was debated was, "Resolved, that National
banks should be permitted to issue, subject to
tax and government supervision, notes based
on their general assets." The Class of 1909
had the affirmative, and the Class of 1908 the
negative. Messrs. Marvel, Blum and Fisher
spoke on the affirmative, and the Class of
1908 was represented by Mr. Mann, Mr. McCauley and Mr. Hutzler. The alternates for
the Juniors and Seniors were Messrs.
Guerard, and Sykes, respectively, and the
advisers were Mr. Corner and Mr. Wright.
The debate was very close, but the judges,
who were Dr. Fabian Franklin, George R.
Willis, Esq., and George L. P. Radcliffe,
Esq., decided in favor of the negative. In
the meantime, while the judges were out, the
Mandolin Club played "Lady Laughter."
The hall was very tastefully decorated with
all the Hopkins banners and class flags, and
the stage with palms and carnations. All this
added to the attractiveness of the occasion,
which was indeed most enjoyable.

COMPLAINT TO HIS EMPTY PURSE.
Nickles, nickles, nickels,
Hark, I hear them fall;
Mine go in the gutter,
Yours,against the wall.
Nickles, nickles, nickles,
I see them in my dreams,
I hear the winner's joyful laugh,
I hear the loser's screams.
Nickles, nickles, nickles,
0, hearken as I sing—
The nickles that I won last fall
I've already lost this spring.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

JOINT CONCERT.
Of course, every one has heard about the
Joint Concert by the Musical Clubs of the
Woman's College of Baltimore and the Johns
Hopkins University, to be given Friday,
March 13, in McCoy Hall. Most of the
students, at any rate, have heard the rehearsals of the combined Glee Clubs and combined
Mandolin Clubs. The Clubs have been working very hard to make this concert a complete
success. It has been two years since the
Hopkins Musical Clubs have given a Baltimore
concert, and, therefore, the Management hopes
to fill McCoy Hall to overflowing. Although
the Woman's College and Hopkins gave a
joint concert several years ago, there were no
combined numbers on the program as there
will be this time. A double sextet, composed
of six from each Mandolin Club, will play the
"Sextet from Lucia." There will be three or
four solos, both vocal and instrumental, and a
vocal duet by Miss Bishop and Mr. Uhlig.
The program will close with a concerted piece
by the Glee Clubs. This will be the greatest
thing that the Clubs have ever tried, as there
will be about fifty voices in the chorus.
There is a long list of patronesses of the
most prominent people in Baltimore. Up to
the present time the Management have been
very successful in that most of the patronesses
took the tickets that were sent to them and
have made the returns for them. However,
some of those who have accepted evidently
thought that the tickets, which were enclosed,
were complimentary, which, we are sorry to
say, was not the case.
The reserved seats, which are on sale at
Albaugh's, 109 N. Charles street, are at
present selling very well, and the Management is very much encouraged and expects to
clear several hundred dollars. It must be
remembered that all the seats in the hall will
be reserved at $1.00, 75c. and 50c. The
white tickets, which were sent to the patronesses and which are being sold by the students,
must be exchanged at Albaugh's for reserved
seats, and will not be accepted at the door.
No tickets will be sold at McCoy Hall on
the night of the concert, but if any one comes
with the white tickets and if there are any
reserved seats left, the white tickets will be
exchanged for reserved seats. But we hope

5

that there will be no reserved seats left. The
Management hopes to make enough money to
pay off the old debts of two years ago, and
also to enable the Hopkins Musical Clubs to
take a trip to Washington to give a concert at
their own risk and to take an Easter trip down
the Eastern Shore.
In fact arrangements are being made to
give a concert in Washington either at
Rauscher's or the New Williard ball-room
about the last of March or the first part of
April. The Manager feels confident that if
the Clubs should give the proposed concert in
Washington, it would be a financial success.
He is quite anxious for the Hopkins Musical
Clubs to establish a good reputation in that
city and also the custom of giving an annual
concert there.
The Management wishes to urge, through
the columns of the NEWS-LETTER, that every
student who has not already bought at least
one ticket should do so as soon as he receives
this copy of the paper and come to the concert to-night.

LACROSSE EXCHANCES.
The following clippings, the first from the
.S7ute, of Stevens Institute, the others from
the Harvard Crimson, show that some of our
rivals are keeping wide-awake to the lacrosse
situation :
The spring lacrosse practice will begin
shortly. Last year the team lost but one
game. The team this year will have to work
to beat this record.—The
A meeting of candidates for the University
and Freshman lacrosse teams was held last
night in the Trophy Room of the Union.
L. D. Cox '08, manager of the University
team, outlined the season's plans. Practice
will begin as soon as the handball courts are
clear of snow and will continue daily at 4
o'clock in two squads: the first containing
experienced players and the second the new
candidates, both for the Freshmen and University teams. The class games will be held
as soon as Soldiers Field is available for play.
The second team will be more carefully organized than in previous years and will play
several outside games. In the Easter vacation the University team will go on a southern
trip on which they will play five games. After
the series of league games, a game may be
played with the University of Toronto, the
Canadian champion for three years. The
team is to be coached by a former member of
the Montreal team.—Crimson, March 3.
Preliminary practice for the University and
Freshman lacrosse teams started yesterday

afternoon in the handball courts, back of the
Hemenway Gymnasium. This week will be
devoted to the coaching of new men; experienced men will not be called out until Monday. Practice will be held back of the Gymnasium until Soldiers Field is in a good condition. The class games, in which cups and
class numerals will be rewarded to the winning team, will take place early in April.
The University team will go south during
the Easter recess and play five games, including a probable game with Annapolis.
About the middle of May there will be a trip
to New York, on which two games will be
played. The season will end early in June,
when it is expected that a game will be arranged with the University of Toronto.—
Crimson, March 5.

LACROSSE.
With the first game less than a month off,
the lacrosse team is hard at work trying to
round into shape for its long season. The
squad will probably have gotten out to Homewood by the time this is published, and will
have had an opportunity to see what the new
field is like for lacrosse. As yet the team has
by no means shown the form which is expected of it. This may be due, in part, to
the cramped quarters of the cage, but the
truth of the matter is, that the fellows have
not, on the whole, taken hold of the matter as
they should. Several of the older men have

7

THE NEWS-LETTER.

begun to rest on their laurels, which by the
way are none too brilliant, and evidently
think they need practice only on one or two
days a week. This is not the right spirit.
The fact that there are a number of experienced players back this year is no reason
why the men should become too optimistic
and get swelled heads. The schedule this
year is the best we have ever had and the
hardest. To win those last three games—
Swarthmore, Mt. Washington and Toronto—
will call for the best team the "Black and
Blue" ever turned out, a team that shall be a
unit, and not a collection of individual stars.
Each man owes it to the University and to
his mates on the team to do everything in his
power to put out the strongest team possible.
It is not fair for one or two men to endanger
the championship, which the others will so
earnestly strive for.
The team is far from picked. Who will
play second defense and who are going to get
the home positions? These three places are
being eagerly fought for, and from the present
outlook it will take more than one game to
sift out the men and see who deserves the
place. Ralph Williams, Herbert Price, Oliver
Hopkins and H. L. Russell are all making
strong bids for the defense position, while for
the homes there are candidates galore, the
most promising of which are Mathias, Ciary,
Lowndes, Whitcraft, Stockett, Smith, Wilson
and Tappan. As yet, none have been proved
to be world-beaters.
The trouble from time immemorial has been
to get the attack to work in properly, and this
year bids fair to be a repetition of former
years in that respect. It is to be hoped that
things will be working properly by the time
the first game comes off.
Was there ever a better schedule than the
one arranged for the team this year? Those
last three games in Baltimore will be great,
and if the students don't get behind the team
then, they will never have a better chance.
This year's schedule is worth a whole winter's
training for; there are enough games to look
forward to, and with all these fine games on
our own field Baltimore may expect to see
some mighty good lacrosse. The manager
has done his best to get a schedule; the players
will do their best to bring back another

championship banner, and it is up to the
students to do their best in the way of rooting. Let us have some support such as was
given the football team last fall, and there
will not be much question as to the outcome
of the season, either from a financial or playing point of view.

THE CROSS COUNTRY RUN.
From the way the entries are coming in,
our cross country run, which will be held at
Homewood, Saturday, March 14, will afford
some excellent sport. Lou Conners, of
Wesleyan; Fleming, of George Washington
University; Whit e, of the Bloomingdale
Athletic Club, have entered. Both the
Western High School, of Washington, and
the Cross Country Club, of this city, have also
entered teams of five men. Additional entries
are expected from Pennsylvania, Virginia and
other local organizations.
The run will be conducted on the open
handicap basis. A fine gold pendant medal
has been donated by A. G. Spaulding & Bros.
for first prize, while silver and bronze medals
will go to the second and third men. A banner will also be given to the team of four men
that do the best work in scoring points.
The run will start from Homewood at 2
o'clock, and will go out Charles street avenue
to Belvedere, over Belvedere to Roland avenue;
then to the car barn on the Falls Road and
down the Falls Road to Cold Spring Lane,
thence to Roland avenue, Merryman's Lane,
back to Homewood.
The Hopkins team will be picked from :
Brenton, Breyer, Griffith, Russell, Armstrong,
Burgan, Wolfe, Tappan and Reeside.

THE MEET.
Our meet was a great success this year.
Both the open events and relay races brought
out some of the closest competition of the
year. The speed with which the track events
were run off sets a new mark for this city, for
shortly before 10 o'clock the last race was
over. Great credit is due Mr. Wylie, the
manager of the track team, for the way in
which he overcame the very limited accom-

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

modations of the cage, and caused the meet
to be such a financial and athletic success.
The best feature, however, was that our
own track men won the meet with 17% points.
Mount Washington landed second, with 15
points. It was by the closest kind of a shave
that we won our last 2Y4. points. Four men
were tie in the pole vault with a jump of 10
feet. Not one of these men could get over
the bar at 10 feet, 6 inches, and according to
the inter-collegiate rules the bar could
not be lowered. So there the matter stood.
The judges finally decided to split the points
and let the men draw for the medals. It is
singular to remark that Bridgman, who scored
the winning points for the Varsity, drew a
blank and received no medal.
Our men did excellent work in the distance.
In the mile run Griffith and Breyer won first
and second places, while in the - half mile
Breyer and Wallis came in second and third.
The mile race was a great one, and the time
is believed to have been the fastest ever made
in the cage. Griffith won by making a final
spurt that broke the tape only a few inches
ahead of Breyer. .G. A. Stewart did good
work in the 440, winning second place. Although both Baily and Stollenwerck qualified
in their heat in the 30-yard dash, neither
scored in the finals.
Probably the most interesting event of the
evening was the mile relay between the
Juniors and Freshmen. The race was exceedingly close, for never were the runners
more than 5 or 6 yards apart. The first three
Juniors, Schneeberger, Wylie and Wallis, won
a lead of about 5 yards on their opponents,
Wolfe, Tappan and Burgan. Stollenwerck,
however, the last man for the Freshmen,
gradually overtook Baily, the Junior captain,
and passed him on the last quarter of a lap.

they succeeded in winning both the 1,000yard and mile runs. Brenton won the shorter
event handily and finished second in the mile
run, in which Breyer came first.

THE DANCE.
Since the Editorial on page 3 was put into
type, May the ninth has been definitely fixed
for the last dance of the Hopkins Cotillon
Club.

Local option forms the theme of all our talk

Among the exchanges on the editor's desk
this month is. the Palm, of the Central High
School, of San Juan, Porto Rico. This little
paper, (which is partly in Spanish and partly
in English), is exceedingly well done, and
would cause considerable surprise to those
who vaguely think of Porto Rico as a land of
palm-trees and fiestas and bull-fights. The
following excerpts from the Palm will serve
to show how far the americanization of Porto
Rico has proceeded:

MICHIGAN'S RECORD IN DEBATE.

Michigan holds a unique record in intervarsity debating, For two years, her representatives have won on the same day two
debates, maintaining opposite sides of the
same question, one team in Chicago and one
in Ann Arbor. On Friday, January 17,
Michigan won the second series of intercollegiate debates with Chicago and Northwestern, both, under the rules of the new
triangular Central Debating League, thus
securing the undisputed title of champion of
the league.

When I have fears that Reason's icy hand
Shall still with chilling touch my bounding
blood
Shake up my passion's heat, or stem love's
flood,
Obliterate Romance, with his deep brand;
Or that I of my muse shall lose command
And thus be cast from poesy's brotherhood
To serve thenceforth the ogre long withstood
Philosophy, who will not understand
That love and hate are stronger far to me
Than physic's truest rule, than Nature's
flowers
Or heaven's blue, or bird on forest .tree
More potent are than logic's seeming powers,—
I beat them back and will not be content,
For life's but life when lived with sentiment.

VERY important and vital question in the undergraduate affairs of
most leading American universities is the question of Fraternities.
0
It has been a custom, here at Hopkins, not to discuss any phase of
the Fraternity question in the columns of the Nicws-Lornoz. This
custom, one might almost call it a tradition, has obtained ever since
the foundation of the paper ten years or so ago. But customary
V
though it has been, there is no rule which prohibits such discussions
ISVVVVV*
in this paper and after seriously considering the question, the Board
Editors of the NEWS-LETTER has come to the conclusion that the
of
11
publication of such Fraternity news as would be of interest to other
Fraternities, would tend to bring about better feeling among the Fraternities here at Hopkins. Almost all the other college papers in this country publish such news; some have a
regular "Fraternity" column. Why should not we ? All of us know that one of the
Fraternities here held a Convention in Philadelphia lately; that a member of the Junior Class
was a delegate to the Convention of another Fraternity in Minnesota ten days ago; and that
the Alumni Banquet of a third Fraternity had to be called off owing to the death of one of its
officers. Why ,should not such news be published in this .paper ? It would be of interest to
the student-body; it would interest our subscribers among the Alumni.
Another side of the question is the much-mooted proposition of an inter-fraternity organization, in the nature of a Pan-Hellenic. The NEws-LETTER believes that such an organization, if begun and carried on in the right way, would be of great benefit to the University.
But we can, of course, do nothing to start such a movement. The initiative must come from
the Fraternities themselves. But if such an initiative does come, our columns are at the disposal of all those Who care to discuss their views or suggest plans. Two things, however,
must be emphasized. A Pan-Hellenic must be an entirely non-secret society, and it must be
representative of all of our fraternities.

V.—THE HOUR OF EXTASY.
FROM VERLAINE.

The white moon slants through the gloomy
wood,
From every branch, a voice is heard
In the foliage dark,
Beloved, hark!
From the bank of the stream,
As in a mirror, is seen
The shadow of the willow
The breeze tells of Love's power.
Let us dream !
'Tis the hour !
A vast and tender peace from on high
Descends from yon star in the purple sky
Tis the hour of Extasy !

ELEVENTH ANNUAL INTERCLASS DEBATE AND PUBLIC SPEAKING.
As usual, the Interclass Debate and Public
Speaking Contest proved to be a very interesting affair. This event has become quite
popular, and is looked forward to by a great
many, as was shown by the crowded condition
of McCoy Hall. The program was of the
customary style, being opened with a selection
by the Mandolin Club as the speakers and
judges entered. Dr. French, who presided
over the occasion, then introduced the orators.
Mr. Louis Leopold Mann delivered most
excellently a speech on "True Americanism."
The judges awarded the prize to Mr. Mann,
although they were not unanimous in their
decision. They thought that it was a close
race between Mr. Mann and Mr. Deale, who
made "A Plea for Cuba." Mr. Deale's
delivery was very good and his voice filled
the hall. After the decision of the judges
was announced by L. Edwin Goldman, Esq.,
the Glee Club sang "Rah for Black and Blue."
During this song the students in the back of
the hall joined in the chorus, which tended to
make things more lively and not so solemn as

they usually are on this occasion. The
audience was so appreciative and applauded
so long that, even though the Glee Club had
gone around to the rear of the hall, they sang
"Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land."
Then catne the debate—the really serious
part of the, program. The question which
was debated was, "Resolved, that National
banks should be permitted to issue, subject to
tax and government supervision, notes based
on their general assets." The Class of 1909
had the affirmative, and the Class of 1908 the
negative. Messrs. Marvel, Blum and Fisher
spoke on the affirmative, and the Class of
1908 was represented by Mr. Mann, Mr. McCauley and Mr. Hutzler. The alternates for
the Juniors and Seniors were Messrs.
Guerard, and Sykes, respectively, and the
advisers were Mr. Corner and Mr. Wright.
The debate was very close, but the judges,
who were Dr. Fabian Franklin, George R.
Willis, Esq., and George L. P. Radcliffe,
Esq., decided in favor of the negative. In
the meantime, while the judges were out, the
Mandolin Club played "Lady Laughter."
The hall was very tastefully decorated with
all the Hopkins banners and class flags, and
the stage with palms and carnations. All this
added to the attractiveness of the occasion,
which was indeed most enjoyable.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

JOINT CONCERT.
Of course, every one has heard about the
Joint Concert by the Musical Clubs of the
Woman's College of Baltimore and the Johns
Hopkins University, to be given Friday,
March 13, in McCoy Hall. Most of the
students, at any rate, have heard the rehearsals of the combined Glee Clubs and combined
Mandolin Clubs. The Clubs have been working very hard to make this concert a complete
success. It has been two years since the
Hopkins Musical Clubs have given a Baltimore
concert, and, therefore, the Management hopes
to fill McCoy Hall to overflowing. Although
the Woman's College and Hopkins gave a
joint concert several years ago, there were no
combined numbers on the program as there
will be this time. A double sextet, composed
of six from each Mandolin Club, will play the
"Sextet from Lucia." There will be three or
four solos, both vocal and instrumental, and a
vocal duet by Miss Bishop and Mr. Uhlig.
The program will close with a concerted piece
by the Glee Clubs. This will be the greatest
thing that the Clubs have ever tried, as there
will be about fifty voices in the chorus.
There is a long list of patronesses of the
most prominent people in Baltimore. Up to
the present time the Management have been
very successful in that most of the patronesses
took the tickets that were sent to them and
have made the returns for them. However,
some of those who have accepted evidently
thought that the tickets, which were enclosed,
were complimentary, which, we are sorry to
say, was not the case.
The reserved seats, which are on sale at
Albaugh's, 109 N. Charles street, are at
present selling very well, and the Management is very much encouraged and expects to
clear several hundred dollars. It must be
remembered that all the seats in the hall will
be reserved at $1.00, 75c. and 50c. The
white tickets, which were sent to the patronesses and which are being sold by the students,
must be exchanged at Albaugh's for reserved
seats, and will not be accepted at the door.
No tickets will be sold at McCoy Hall on
the night of the concert, but if any one comes
with the white tickets and if there are any
reserved seats left, the white tickets will be
exchanged for reserved seats. But we hope

5

that there will be no reserved seats left. The
Management hopes to make enough money to
pay off the old debts of two years ago, and
also to enable the Hopkins Musical Clubs to
take a trip to Washington to give a concert at
their own risk and to take an Easter trip down
the Eastern Shore.
In fact arrangements are being made to
give a concert in Washington either at
Rauscher's or the New Williard ball-room
about the last of March or the first part of
April. The Manager feels confident that if
the Clubs should give the proposed concert in
Washington, it would be a financial success.
He is quite anxious for the Hopkins Musical
Clubs to establish a good reputation in that
city and also the custom of giving an annual
concert there.
The Management wishes to urge, through
the columns of the NEWS-LETTER, that every
student who has not already bought at least
one ticket should do so as soon as he receives
this copy of the paper and come to the concert to-night.

LACROSSE EXCHANCES.
The following clippings, the first from the
.S7ute, of Stevens Institute, the others from
the Harvard Crimson, show that some of our
rivals are keeping wide-awake to the lacrosse
situation :
The spring lacrosse practice will begin
shortly. Last year the team lost but one
game. The team this year will have to work
to beat this record.—The
A meeting of candidates for the University
and Freshman lacrosse teams was held last
night in the Trophy Room of the Union.
L. D. Cox '08, manager of the University
team, outlined the season's plans. Practice
will begin as soon as the handball courts are
clear of snow and will continue daily at 4
o'clock in two squads: the first containing
experienced players and the second the new
candidates, both for the Freshmen and University teams. The class games will be held
as soon as Soldiers Field is available for play.
The second team will be more carefully organized than in previous years and will play
several outside games. In the Easter vacation the University team will go on a southern
trip on which they will play five games. After
the series of league games, a game may be
played with the University of Toronto, the
Canadian champion for three years. The
team is to be coached by a former member of
the Montreal team.—Crimson, March 3.
Preliminary practice for the University and
Freshman lacrosse teams started yesterday

afternoon in the handball courts, back of the
Hemenway Gymnasium. This week will be
devoted to the coaching of new men; experienced men will not be called out until Monday. Practice will be held back of the Gymnasium until Soldiers Field is in a good condition. The class games, in which cups and
class numerals will be rewarded to the winning team, will take place early in April.
The University team will go south during
the Easter recess and play five games, including a probable game with Annapolis.
About the middle of May there will be a trip
to New York, on which two games will be
played. The season will end early in June,
when it is expected that a game will be arranged with the University of Toronto.—
Crimson, March 5.

LACROSSE.
With the first game less than a month off,
the lacrosse team is hard at work trying to
round into shape for its long season. The
squad will probably have gotten out to Homewood by the time this is published, and will
have had an opportunity to see what the new
field is like for lacrosse. As yet the team has
by no means shown the form which is expected of it. This may be due, in part, to
the cramped quarters of the cage, but the
truth of the matter is, that the fellows have
not, on the whole, taken hold of the matter as
they should. Several of the older men have

7

THE NEWS-LETTER.

begun to rest on their laurels, which by the
way are none too brilliant, and evidently
think they need practice only on one or two
days a week. This is not the right spirit.
The fact that there are a number of experienced players back this year is no reason
why the men should become too optimistic
and get swelled heads. The schedule this
year is the best we have ever had and the
hardest. To win those last three games—
Swarthmore, Mt. Washington and Toronto—
will call for the best team the "Black and
Blue" ever turned out, a team that shall be a
unit, and not a collection of individual stars.
Each man owes it to the University and to
his mates on the team to do everything in his
power to put out the strongest team possible.
It is not fair for one or two men to endanger
the championship, which the others will so
earnestly strive for.
The team is far from picked. Who will
play second defense and who are going to get
the home positions? These three places are
being eagerly fought for, and from the present
outlook it will take more than one game to
sift out the men and see who deserves the
place. Ralph Williams, Herbert Price, Oliver
Hopkins and H. L. Russell are all making
strong bids for the defense position, while for
the homes there are candidates galore, the
most promising of which are Mathias, Ciary,
Lowndes, Whitcraft, Stockett, Smith, Wilson
and Tappan. As yet, none have been proved
to be world-beaters.
The trouble from time immemorial has been
to get the attack to work in properly, and this
year bids fair to be a repetition of former
years in that respect. It is to be hoped that
things will be working properly by the time
the first game comes off.
Was there ever a better schedule than the
one arranged for the team this year? Those
last three games in Baltimore will be great,
and if the students don't get behind the team
then, they will never have a better chance.
This year's schedule is worth a whole winter's
training for; there are enough games to look
forward to, and with all these fine games on
our own field Baltimore may expect to see
some mighty good lacrosse. The manager
has done his best to get a schedule; the players
will do their best to bring back another

championship banner, and it is up to the
students to do their best in the way of rooting. Let us have some support such as was
given the football team last fall, and there
will not be much question as to the outcome
of the season, either from a financial or playing point of view.

THE CROSS COUNTRY RUN.
From the way the entries are coming in,
our cross country run, which will be held at
Homewood, Saturday, March 14, will afford
some excellent sport. Lou Conners, of
Wesleyan; Fleming, of George Washington
University; Whit e, of the Bloomingdale
Athletic Club, have entered. Both the
Western High School, of Washington, and
the Cross Country Club, of this city, have also
entered teams of five men. Additional entries
are expected from Pennsylvania, Virginia and
other local organizations.
The run will be conducted on the open
handicap basis. A fine gold pendant medal
has been donated by A. G. Spaulding & Bros.
for first prize, while silver and bronze medals
will go to the second and third men. A banner will also be given to the team of four men
that do the best work in scoring points.
The run will start from Homewood at 2
o'clock, and will go out Charles street avenue
to Belvedere, over Belvedere to Roland avenue;
then to the car barn on the Falls Road and
down the Falls Road to Cold Spring Lane,
thence to Roland avenue, Merryman's Lane,
back to Homewood.
The Hopkins team will be picked from :
Brenton, Breyer, Griffith, Russell, Armstrong,
Burgan, Wolfe, Tappan and Reeside.

THE MEET.
Our meet was a great success this year.
Both the open events and relay races brought
out some of the closest competition of the
year. The speed with which the track events
were run off sets a new mark for this city, for
shortly before 10 o'clock the last race was
over. Great credit is due Mr. Wylie, the
manager of the track team, for the way in
which he overcame the very limited accom-

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

modations of the cage, and caused the meet
to be such a financial and athletic success.
The best feature, however, was that our
own track men won the meet with 17% points.
Mount Washington landed second, with 15
points. It was by the closest kind of a shave
that we won our last 2Y4. points. Four men
were tie in the pole vault with a jump of 10
feet. Not one of these men could get over
the bar at 10 feet, 6 inches, and according to
the inter-collegiate rules the bar could
not be lowered. So there the matter stood.
The judges finally decided to split the points
and let the men draw for the medals. It is
singular to remark that Bridgman, who scored
the winning points for the Varsity, drew a
blank and received no medal.
Our men did excellent work in the distance.
In the mile run Griffith and Breyer won first
and second places, while in the - half mile
Breyer and Wallis came in second and third.
The mile race was a great one, and the time
is believed to have been the fastest ever made
in the cage. Griffith won by making a final
spurt that broke the tape only a few inches
ahead of Breyer. .G. A. Stewart did good
work in the 440, winning second place. Although both Baily and Stollenwerck qualified
in their heat in the 30-yard dash, neither
scored in the finals.
Probably the most interesting event of the
evening was the mile relay between the
Juniors and Freshmen. The race was exceedingly close, for never were the runners
more than 5 or 6 yards apart. The first three
Juniors, Schneeberger, Wylie and Wallis, won
a lead of about 5 yards on their opponents,
Wolfe, Tappan and Burgan. Stollenwerck,
however, the last man for the Freshmen,
gradually overtook Baily, the Junior captain,
and passed him on the last quarter of a lap.

they succeeded in winning both the 1,000yard and mile runs. Brenton won the shorter
event handily and finished second in the mile
run, in which Breyer came first.

MICHIGAN'S RECORD IN DEBATE.

Michigan holds a unique record in intervarsity debating, For two years, her representatives have won on the same day two
debates, maintaining opposite sides of the
same question, one team in Chicago and one
in Ann Arbor. On Friday, January 17,
Michigan won the second series of intercollegiate debates with Chicago and Northwestern, both, under the rules of the new
triangular Central Debating League, thus
securing the undisputed title of champion of
the league.

When I have fears that Reason's icy hand
Shall still with chilling touch my bounding
blood
Shake up my passion's heat, or stem love's
flood,
Obliterate Romance, with his deep brand;
Or that I of my muse shall lose command
And thus be cast from poesy's brotherhood
To serve thenceforth the ogre long withstood
Philosophy, who will not understand
That love and hate are stronger far to me
Than physic's truest rule, than Nature's
flowers
Or heaven's blue, or bird on forest .tree
More potent are than logic's seeming powers,—
I beat them back and will not be content,
For life's but life when lived with sentiment.
